intro: Astracantha bactriana, commonly known as the Afghan milkweed, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, woolly stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers. The plant produces a milky sap that is toxic and can cause skin irritation. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in rocky or mountainous terrain. Astracantha bactriana is adapted to survive in harsh climates with minimal water availability.
